case_name: Pramatha Nath Talukdar and Saurindra Mohan Basu v. Saroj Ranjan Sarkar

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 75 and 77 of 1961 were filed by special leave in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 75 and 77 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 22-23, 1960, and from the order dated March 17, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Cr. Revision Nos. 1019 and 681 of 1959.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on April 10, 1961 to Pramatha Nath Talukdar and Saurindra Mohan Basu.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated April 10, 1961 this Court granted special leave asked for by the two appellants herein, Pramatha Nath Talukdar and Saurindra Mohan Basu, to appeal to this Court from two orders made by the High Court of Calcutta, one dated December 22/23, 1960 and the other dated March 17, 1961.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Special Bench dismissed revisions on December 22/23, 1960 against Chief Presidency Magistrate's order dated April 11, 1959 issuing processes under ss. 467, 471/109 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: By the first order a Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court dismissed two applications in revision which the appellants had made to the said High Court against an order of the Chief Presidency Magistrate of Calcutta dated April 11, 1959 by which the said Magistrate issued processes against the two appellants for offences alleged to have been committed by them under ss. 467 and 471 read with s. 109 of the Indian penal Code on a complaint made by Saroj Ranjan Sarkar, respondent herein.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate issued processes on April 11, 1959 against Pramatha Nath Talukdar and Saurindra Mohan Basu on second complaint by Saroj Ranjan Sarkar.

anchor.surface_text: against an order of the Chief Presidency Magistrate of Calcutta dated April 11, 1959 by which the said Magistrate issued processes against the two appellants for offences alleged to have been committed by them under ss. 467 and 471 read with s. 109 of the Indian penal Code on a complaint made by Saroj Ranjan Sarkar, respondent herein.

facts.text: Second complaint filed by Saroj Ranjan Sarkar on April 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Saroj Ranjan Sarkar, who is the youngest brother of the late Nalini Ranjan Sakar-a well-known public man, financier and industrialist of Bengal-filed a petition of complaint in the court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta. On April 3, 1959, I do not pause here to state the allegations made in that petition, a shall have occasion to refer to them in detail later on.

facts.text: First complaint filed by Promode Ranjan Sarkar on March 17, 1954, dismissed under s.203 CrPC on August 6, 1954 by Chief Presidency Magistrate N.C. Chakravarti.

anchor.surface_text: A previous complaint on more or less the same allegations was made by Promode Ranjan Sarkar, second brother of the late Nalini Ranjan Sarkar. That complaint was made on March 17, 1954 and was dismissed under s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure by the then Chief Presidency Magistrate, Shri N. C. Chakravarti, on August 6, 1954.

facts.text: Revision against first complaint dismissal filed, dismissed by Calcutta High Court (Debabrata Mookerjee J.) on July 8, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, an application in revision was made by Promode Ranjan Sarkar to the High Court of Calcutta, which gave rise to Revision Case No. 1059 of 1954. This application in revision was dismissed on July 8, 1955 by Debabrata Mookerjee,

facts.text: Certificate under Art.134(1)(c) refused by Calcutta High Court on September 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Promode Ranjan Sarkar then applied for a certificate under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, but such a certificate was refused by a Bench of the Calcutta High Court on September 1, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on February 13, 1956 for appeal from first complaint proceedings; appeal withdrawn on March 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Promode Ranjan Sarkar applied for special leave from this Court and obtained such leave on February 13, 1956. An appeal was filed in pursuance of that special leave, but ultimately Promode Ranjan Sarkar withdrew his appeal by filing a petition on February 3, 1959.

facts.text: Nalini Ranjan Sarkar died on January 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Nalini Ranjan Sarkar died on January 25, 1953.

facts.text: Alleged unregistered deed of agreement dated January 19, 1948 appointing Pramatha Nath Talukdar as Managing Director of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd., forged.

anchor.surface_text: An unregistered deed of agreement purporting to have been executed by the late Nalini Ranjan Sarkar as Governing Director of N. Sarkar Co. Ltd. on January 19, 1948 appointing Pramatha Nath Talukdar as the Managing Director of N. R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. on a remuneration of Rs. 1500-100-2000 per month.

facts.text: Alleged transfer deed of 1000 shares dated February 5, 1951 from Nalini Ranjan Sarkar to Pramatha Nath Talukdar, forged.

anchor.surface_text: A transfer deed in respect of 1000 shares of N. R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. which were said to have been entrusted to Pramatha Nath Talukdar, transfering them to the latter for and alleged consideration of rupees one lac purporting to have been executed by the late Nalini Ranjan Sarkar on February 5, 1951

facts.text: Alleged minutes of Board meeting dated January 16, 1948 of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. bearing Nalini Ranjan Sarkar's signature, forged.

anchor.surface_text: Minutes of the proceedings of the Board meeting of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. dated January 16, 1948 purporting to bear the signature of the late Nalini Ranjan Sarkar and containing a resolution to the effect that the Governing Director approved of a draft agreement

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate (Bijayesh Mukherjee) found prima facie case of forgery for minutes dated Jan 16, 1948 and deed dated Jan 19, 1948; issued process against two appellants.

anchor.surface_text: the relevant materials in the record showed prima facie that the minutes of the proceedings dated January 16, 1948 were forged and so also the unregistered deed of agreement dated January, 19, 1948.

facts.text: No undue delay in second complaint considering withdrawal of Supreme Court appeal on March 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: there was no delay in making the second complaint, if one had regard to the circumstances which led to the first complaint and the withdrawal of the appeal in the Supreme Court on March 12, 1959 arising out of the order made on the first complaint

facts.text: Telephone number City 6091 on minutes paper did not exist until December 1948; connection obtained March 18, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: the minutes were typed on a sheet of paper bearing the letter-head N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. with telephone number City 6091 printed thereon but the City Exchange did not come into existence until December, 1948 and the telephone connection relating to no City 6091 was obtained for the first time by the Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd. on or about March 18, 1949

facts.text: Deed of trust executed by Nalini Ranjan Sarkar on July 31, 1951 for 3649 shares in N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1951 Nalini Ranjan Sarkar executed a deed of trust in respect of 3649 shares out of the shares held by him in N. R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. By the said trust-deed he appointed Promode Ranjan Sarkar, Pramatha Nath Talukdar and Narendra Nath Law as the trustees

facts.text: Nalini Ranjan Sarkar obtained leave of absence from N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. on January 4, 1948; assumed office as Finance Minister West Bengal on January 23, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On January 4, 1948 he obtained leave of absence from the Directors of N. Sarkar Co. Ltd. for a period of one year with a view to joining the Ministry in West Bengal and he assumed office as Finance Minister of the West Bengal Government on January 23, 1948.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Division Bench referred revisions to Special Bench; Special Bench dismissed on Dec 22/23, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: These applications in revision were first heard by a division Bench of two Judges of the Calcutta High Court, P. B. Mukherjee and H. K. Bose, JJ. ... This Special Bench heard the two applications in revision and dismissed them by its order dated December 22/23, 1960.

facts.text: Certificate under Art.134(1)(c) refused by Division Bench on March 17, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: By the second order a Division Bench of the said High Court refused the prayer of the appellants for a certificate under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution of India that the case was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Pramatha Nath Talukdar resigned from Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd. on July 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1953, i.e. about six months after the death of Nalini Ranjan Sarkar Pramatha Nath Talukdar resigned from his salaried post under the Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd.

facts.text: Board meeting of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. on September 22, 1953 renewed appointment of Pramatha Nath Talukdar as Managing Director for seven years.

anchor.surface_text: On September 22, 1953 a meeting of the Board of Directors of N.R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. was held. It was alleged that the meeting was held irregularly without any agenda and a resolution was adopted, despite Promode Ranjan Sarkars protest, by which the appointment of Pramatha Nath Talukdar as Managing Director of N. R. Sarkar Co. Ltd. was renewed for seven years.

facts.text: Second complaint not barred by dismissal of first; exceptional circumstances exist including misdirection by first Magistrate and new evidence on telephone number.

anchor.surface_text: I am of the view that there is substance in this contention. Section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that the Magistrate may dismiss the complaint...

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate (N.C. Chakravarti) misdirected himself in first complaint by applying conviction standards under ss.203/204 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: dealing with the first complaint the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate proceeded to consider not whether there was sufficient ground for proceeding within the meaning of ss. 203 and 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure but whether there was sufficient evidence for conviction of the accused persons.

facts.text: City Exchange came into existence in December 1948; not considered in first complaint.

anchor.surface_text: When the first complaint was dealt with by the Chief Presidency Magistrate no evidence was led to show that the City Exchange did not come into existence until December, 1948

issues.text: The principal question which arises for decision in these two appeals is whether a second complaint can be entertained by a Magistrate who or whose predecessor had, on the same or similar allegation, dismissed a previous complaint, and if so in what circumstances should such a second complaint be entertained.

anchor.surface_text: The principal question which arises for decision in these two appeals is whether a second complaint can be entertained by a Magistrate who or whose predecessor had, on the same or similar allegation, dismissed a previous complaint, and if so in what circumstances should such a second complaint be entertained.

issues.text: whether the Special Bench was lawfully in seizin of the case and was competent to deal with the applications in revision.

anchor.surface_text: Three questions were agitated before the Special Bench. The first was whether the Special Bench was lawfully in seizin of the case and was competent to deal with the applications in revision.

issues.text: whether the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offences alleged, in the absence of a sanction under s. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The second was whether the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offences alleged, in the absence of a sanction under s. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

issues.text: whether it was open to the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate to entertain a second complaint on the same allegations when his predecessor had dismissed the first complaint and if it was open to him to entertain the second complaint should he have entertained it in the circumstances of the present case?

anchor.surface_text: The third and the principal question was whether it was open to the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate to entertain a second complaint on the same allegations when his predecessor had dismissed the first complaint and if it was open to him to entertain the second complaint should he have entertained it in the circumstances of the present case ?

issues.text: whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A (2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A (2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

issues.text: when the first complaint containing more or less the same allegations was dismissed under s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure by the Chief Presidency Magistrate, it was not at all open to his successor to entertain the second complaint.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of one of the appellants... has argued before us that when the first complaint containing more or less the same allegations was dismissed under s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure by the Chief Presidency Magistrate, it was not at all open to his successor to entertain the second complaint.

issues.text: What is the true scope and effect of the expression sufficient ground for proceeding occurring in ss. 203 and 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure?

issues.answer: prima facie case, not conviction standard

anchor.surface_text: dealing with the first complaint the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate proceeded to consider not whether there was sufficient ground for proceeding within the meaning of ss. 203 and 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure but whether there was sufficient evidence for conviction of the accused persons.

arguments.claim: S.403 CrPC does not bar second complaint on dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is relevant to this argument. It embodies the well- established rule of common law that a man may not be put twice in peril for the same offence

arguments.claim: Abetment by conspiracy u/s 107/109 distinct from criminal conspiracy u/s 120A/B.

anchor.surface_text: It then pointed out that the Chief Presidency Magistrate did not take cognizance of the offence of criminal conspiracy to commit forgery which would be punishable under s. 120B read with s. 467 of the Indian Penal Code, but he took cognizance of the offence of abetment of forgery punishable under s. 467 read with s. 109

holdings.text: The special Bench constituted by the Chief Justice was lawfully in seisin of the case and was competent to deal with it. The objection as to the jurisdiction of the special Bench to hear the case was, in my opinion, rightly overruled by it.

anchor.surface_text: My conclusion, therefore, is that there was nothing illegal in the Division Bench consisting of Mukherjee and Bose. JJ. referring the case back to the Chief Justice nor was there anything illegal in the Chief Justice constituting a special Bench of three Judges to hear the applications in revision. The special Benc

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chief Justice has inherent power under court rules to constitute larger benches on reference; absence of specific proviso does not limit this power; aligns with principles for handling important questions differing from prior benches.

holdings.text: The proper test [for s.196A] should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary... [Allegations disclose abetment by conspiracy u/s 109 IPC, not criminal conspiracy u/s 120B IPC].

anchor.surface_text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A (2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between criminal conspiracy (mere agreement u/s 120A/B) requiring sanction and abetment by conspiracy (agreement + overt act u/s 107/109) not requiring sanction; complaint alleges overt acts of forgery/use.

holdings.text: In my opinion, the special Bench rightly overruled the objection as to the alleged violation of the provisions of s. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: I think that there are no good reasons for holding that the view taken by the special Bench is not correct. In my opinion, the special Bench rightly overruled the objection as to the alleged violation of the provisions of s. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Complaint discloses substantive forgery/abetment offences not requiring sanction; cannot evade by drafting; follows Basir-ul-Huq precedent on multiple offences.

holdings.text: There is nothing in law which prohibits the entertainment of a second complaint on the same allegations when a previous complaint had been dismissed under s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: I accept the view expressed by the High Courts that there is nothing in law which prohibits the entertainment of a second complaint on the same allegations when a previous complaint had been dismissed under s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.403 Explanation clarifies dismissal not acquittal; no statutory bar; follows Full Bench and other HC precedents overruling Nilratan Sen/Kamal Chandra.

holdings.text: Exceptional circumstances must exist for the entertainment of a second complaint... manifest error or manifest miscarriage of justice, or... new facts which the complainant had no knowledge of or could not with reasonable diligence have brought forward.

anchor.surface_text: I also accept the view that as a rule of necessary caution... exceptional circumstances must exist for the entertainment of a second complaint on the same allegations... plainly satisfied that there has been some manifest error or manifest miscarriage of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule of caution from precedents like Queen Empress v. Dolegobind Dass, Hansabai; balances complainant rights and accused protection from vexation.

holdings.text: The learned Chief Presidency Magistrate [in first complaint] completely misdirected himself as to the true scope and effect of ss. 203 and 204... resulted in a manifest miscarriage of justice.

anchor.surface_text: dealing with the first complaint the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate proceeded to consider not whether there was sufficient ground for proceeding within the meaning of ss. 203 and 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure but whether there was sufficient evidence for conviction of the accused persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sufficient ground = prima facie case justifying process (per Vadilal Panchal/Ramgopal); first magistrate applied conviction standard on circumstantial evidence.

holdings.text: The matter relating to the City Exchange and in particular telephone number City 6091 was not at all considered when the first complaint was dismissed under s. 203... This would... have great relevance and bearing on the allegation of forgery.

anchor.surface_text: When the first complaint was dealt with by the Chief Presidency Magistrate no evidence was led to show that the City Exchange did not come into existence until December, 1948

holdings.reasoning_summary: New evidence not considered earlier; decisive for forgery (post-dates document); fulfills exceptional circumstance test.

holdings.text: There was a prima facie case against [both] appellants.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate found that there was a prima facie case against Saurindra Mohan Basu. He had attested the signature of the late Nalini Ranjan Sarkar and if that signature was forged, then that would be prima facie evidence against Saurindra Mohan Basu also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Attestation of forged signature; materials support prima facie forgery for both documents/minutes.

holdings.text: There are no good grounds for interfering with the judgment and order of the Special Bench dated December 22/23, 1960. I would accordingly dismiss the two appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons I have come to the conclusion that there are no good grounds for interfering with the judgment and order of the Special Bench dated December 22/33, 1960. I would accordingly dismiss the two appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exceptional circumstances exist; lower courts correct on facts/law; serves justice.
